div.p: this is not an expert presentation this
is the data privacy equivalent of a
third grader doing a book report so
audience participation how many other
people other than you obviously has the
same combination of zip code birth date
including year and sex show of hands
five five or more four three two one or
zero or negative one yes sir so for
eighty-seven percent of the population
the answer is zero that's one study to
some other studies that have it down in
more in the low 60s but that the point
of this is to show that very few data
points can uniquely identify you the
second what I've also learned and this I
again this is a book report of an
article in it or long paper air Brook
the idea that in the theme of the paper
was that anonymization does isn't
sufficient anymore and we need to change
basically our privacy laws to reflect
that so an open data person
well-intentioned researcher what they
generally do is they have a data set it
may include sensitive information what
they do appropriately is redo remove the
personally identifiable information the
PII you've probably heard of that
includes name social security number
address etc things like that and then
they publish the data and they think
they're in good shape here's what then
can happen so that green database with
the personal information sliced off of
it now can be combined with
other databases that live out there so
that that database doesn't live in a
vacuum or in isolation it can be
combined with other data and so you can
take that data where people do know who
you are where you have personally
identifiable information you have common
fields you can combine those two and you
can get a lot more information and so
for example I had a friend show me last
week the voter file so he's a political
guy and he showed me that my data in the
voter file in the NGP van it's called
and it's it's a little scary what they
know or what they think they know and
this process can continue so it's not
just that one database they can augment
that with another database and another
and another through a process called
accretion and build up a lot of
information so now I have a bigger
better more dangerous database so the so
wat here is that simply removing
personally identifiable information
often isn't enough so when Tom talked
about generalizing to a census tract or

p.span: 15 minute windows etc that's a slightly

div.p: different technique generalization which
is also necessary but the key point here
is it's never perfect because you can
take one database get a little bit of
information get another another database
get a little bit more information build
that up and what's the public policy
implication for this is that data
privacy laws generally focus on removing
pup personally identifiable information
and then they give you what's called
safe harbor basically saying if you
follow these rules then you can't be
sued so the recommendation from this
paper is there's a lot more that needs
to be done with privacy laws let's go
well beyond PII and factory in other
considerations thanks
you
